# INTRODUCTION TO

# THE ULTRAMIND SOLUTION

BY MARTHA HERBERT, M.D., PH.D.

<!-- chunk -->

### Assistant Professor of Neurology, Harvard Medical School,

<!-- chunk -->

### and Director of Transcend Research Program,

<!-- chunk -->

### Massachusetts General Hospital

<!-- chunk -->

### In the twenty-first century the watchword of biology is “systems.” As our

<!-- chunk -->

### technologies race ahead in sophistication, we are being flooded with evidence

<!-- chunk -->

### for the integration of functions in our brains and bodies. Things are very

<!-- chunk -->

### connected, and they are very interdependent. Gone is the single gene acting by

<!-- chunk -->

### itself; it has been replaced by networks. And gone is genetics acting by itself—

<!-- chunk -->

### this has been replaced by integration across levels. Genomics, proteomics,

<!-- chunk -->

### metabolomics, and many more “omics” are all intertwined. This is the new

<!-- chunk -->

### “systems biology.”

<!-- chunk -->

### What does this have to do with our health? In the twentieth century,

<!-- chunk -->

### medicine chopped the body up into specialties—neurology, cardiology,

<!-- chunk -->

### gastroenterology, and endocrinology. Specialists zoomed into their corner of the

<!-- chunk -->

### body; but who was minding the whole picture? Very few doctors have had that

<!-- chunk -->

### skill. Systems biology demands a fresh approach, and that’s where Functional

<!-- chunk -->

### Medicine comes in. Rather than treating the body as a collection of separate

<!-- chunk -->

### organ systems, it looks at how our cells and systems flourish and how they get

<!-- chunk -->

### into trouble. Functional Medicine is the practical interface for systems biology in

<!-- chunk -->

### clinical care. It looks for system problems so it can catch things early and treat

<!-- chunk -->

### root causes rather than symptoms.

<!-- chunk -->

### In the twenty-first century it is also becoming clear that the brain is deeply

<!-- chunk -->

### linked to the body, and that the brain and body profoundly shape each other. If

<!-- chunk -->

### the brain is in the body, and the body systems are in trouble, the brain will be in

<!-- chunk -->

### trouble too. Many of the systems commonly unwell in the body will also be

<!-- chunk -->

### unwell in the brain. Dr. Hyman uses Functional Medicine to show that if you

<!-- chunk -->

### treat these unwell systems, you help your body and that helps your brain too.

<!-- chunk -->

### The chemical imbalances underlying “psychiatric illness” can now be seen

<!-- chunk -->

### as linked to more systemic chemical, metabolic problems, which can be treated

<!-- chunk -->

### at the bodily level. While just treating the brain chemistry can lead to drug

<!-- chunk -->

### dependence, treating systemic chemistry can fix the brain chemistry imbalance

<!-- chunk -->

### and lead to real sustainable healing.

<!-- chunk -->

### With the onslaught of so much stress and so many chemical and other

<!-- chunk -->

### environmental challenges, it’s no wonder that our body systems are challenged,

<!-- chunk -->

### and that our brain function is not what it should be. Dr. Hyman’s seven keys to

<!-- chunk -->

### UltraWellness offer a clear approach to supporting and healing our core

<!-- chunk -->

### functional systems. While more research is important, we know enough to deal

<!-- chunk -->

### intelligently with these challenges right now, and Dr. Hyman shows not only

<!-- chunk -->

### why but how.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### memory loss, brain fog, attention deficit disorder or ADD, autism, and dementia

# The Myth of Diagnosis: If You Know the Name of

# Your Disease, You Know What’s Wrong with You

<!-- chunk -->

### neurology, and it is the single biggest obstacle to changing the way we do things

### and finding the answers to our health problems.

### The problem is simply this—we are in the naming and blaming game in

<!-- chunk -->

### medicine. It is what we were trained to do. Find the name of the “disease,” then

<!-- chunk -->

### match the drug to the disease. You have “depression,” so you need an

<!-- chunk -->

### “antidepressant.” You are “anxious,” so you need an “antianxiety” medication.

<!-- chunk -->

### useless, and often dangerous. In some ways it’s even tyrannical. Once you have a

<!-- chunk -->

### label, you are put in the group of people who have the same label, and it is

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### Dr. David Rosenhan, a Stanford University professor of law and psychology,

### hospitals across the country.

<!-- chunk -->

### doesn’t matter what specialty your disease falls under. As Pierre Laplace, the

<!-- chunk -->

### Celeste, a very few fundamental laws can explain an extraordinary number of

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### ICD-9. In almost every one of the diseases listed in that “bible,” the same few

<!-- chunk -->

# The Brain-Body Separation Myth: Your Brain Is

# Protected from Your Body

<!-- chunk -->

### The idea that the brain and the body are separated is a solid, well-established

<!-- chunk -->

### belief. All doctors are trained in the absolute nature of the blood–brain barrier—

<!-- chunk -->

### a wall of tightly packed cells lining the smallest blood vessels of the brain, called

<!-- chunk -->

### capillaries, and a back-up defensive team of astrocytes (star-shaped cells of the

<!-- chunk -->

### glia) that holds this tightly packed wall together.

<!-- chunk -->

### This barrier is designed to keep out toxic influences and infections, but let

<!-- chunk -->

### metabolically necessary ingredients like sugars, fatty acids, and amino acids

<!-- chunk -->

### through.

<!-- chunk -->

### Because we know this barrier exists, we believe that what happens in the

<!-- chunk -->

### brain stays in the brain and what happens in the body stays in the body. Like an

<!-- chunk -->

### iron curtain, that barrier is never breached.

<!-- chunk -->

### There is only one problem with this theory.

<!-- chunk -->

### The blood–brain barrier is really just a partial barrier.

<!-- chunk -->

### We now know the brain can become leaky and the barrier permeable under

<!-- chunk -->

### many conditions—poor nutrition, stress, infection, digestive imbalances, toxic

<!-- chunk -->

### injury, and allergy. The brain, in fact, reads what is happening in the rest of the

<!-- chunk -->

### body even under normal conditions of life.

<!-- chunk -->

### What you do to your body you do to your brain.

<!-- chunk -->

### Let’s take a brief look at childhood autism and Alzheimer’s to illustrate the

<!-- chunk -->

### frailty of the myth that the brain is walled off from the body.

<!-- chunk -->

### Dr. Martha Herbert is an assistant professor of neurology at Harvard Medical

<!-- chunk -->

### School and the director of TRANSCEND (Treatment, Research, and

<!-- chunk -->

### Neuroscience Evaluation of Neurodevelopmental Disorders). Her work in autism

<!-- chunk -->

### behavioral symptoms found in autistic children.

<!-- chunk -->

### A brain disorder, or a disorder that affects the brain?”

### she explains how the

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### the inability to talk, connect with other people, or produce odd repetitive

<!-- chunk -->

### behaviors, have their root not in the brain but in problems with the digestive

<!-- chunk -->

### system and the immune system.

<!-- chunk -->

### stresses and toxins.

<!-- chunk -->

### abnormalities? After examining all the accumulated research on autism,

<!-- chunk -->

### perhaps. These swollen brains are filled with activated immune cells and

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### Unfortunately, we live not only in a sea of toxic chemicals but also of toxic

<!-- chunk -->

### this research in his paper “Children’s Cognitive Health: The Influence of

<!-- chunk -->

### Environmental Chemical Exposures.”

### Lead was the first toxic heavy metal to be identified, and some action has

<!-- chunk -->

### been taken regarding lead exposure in our society. Before lead paint and leaded

<!-- chunk -->

### gasoline were banned, exposure levels were much higher. However, they are still

<!-- chunk -->

### a major problem.

<!-- chunk -->

### Toxic metals, like lead and mercury, are highly persistent in the

<!-- chunk -->

### environment and can be carried far distances in the atmosphere, getting

<!-- chunk -->

### deposited far from their place of origin.

<!-- chunk -->

### For example, coal-burning, lead-and mercury-belching smokestacks in

<!-- chunk -->

### China send their toxic load to the most remote and wild areas of America. Lead

<!-- chunk -->

### and mercury from facilities like these also end up on our driveways and streets

<!-- chunk -->

### and on our carpets and floors where children play. (That’s not to mention all the

<!-- chunk -->

### lead-painted toys from China.)

<!-- chunk -->

### Dr. Herbert Needleman examined the effects of lead on 2,146 children in

<!-- chunk -->

### first and second grade in Alabama.


<!-- chunk -->

### He looked at lead levels in teeth, not in

<!-- chunk -->

### blood, to assess long-term exposure.

<!-- chunk -->

### Not only did the children with the highest levels of lead have the lowest

<!-- chunk -->

### IQs, but they were also more distractible, dependent, disorganized, hyperactive,

<!-- chunk -->

### and impulsive, and had difficulty following simple directions. There were no

<!-- chunk -->

### children in the high-lead group that had IQs over 125, while 5 percent in the

<!-- chunk -->

### low-lead group did.

<!-- chunk -->

### Dr. Needleman did a follow-up study


<!-- chunk -->

### on these children that found the

<!-- chunk -->

### lead-exposed children experienced serious consequences when they got older.

<!-- chunk -->

### They faced a higher rate of high school dropout, a greater likelihood of reading

<!-- chunk -->

### disability, lower class standing in high school, increased absenteeism, lower

<!-- chunk -->

### vocabulary and grammatical-reasoning scores, poorer hand-eye coordination,

<!-- chunk -->

### longer reaction times, and slower finger tapping.

<!-- chunk -->

### They were also more likely to have episodes of juvenile delinquency.

<!-- chunk -->

### In the 1950s the American government set safe levels of lead at

<!-- chunk -->

### micrograms per deciliter of blood as the upper limit of “normal.” Considering

<!-- chunk -->

### severe brain damage occurs at 100 micrograms per deciliter, and death at

<!-- chunk -->

### micrograms per deciliter, this decision is perplexing.

<!-- chunk -->

### The “safe” level was decreased to 40 in 1971, 30 in 1975, 25 in 1985, and

<!-- chunk -->

### 10 in 1991.

<!-- chunk -->

### But recent studies show that the greatest drop-off in IQ scores happens

<!-- chunk -->

### between a level of 1 and 10 micrograms per deciliter.


<!-- chunk -->

### This is particularly scary

<!-- chunk -->

### since more than 10 percent of poor and inner-city children have lead exposure

<!-- chunk -->

### levels over 10 micrograms per deciliter!

<!-- chunk -->

### Of course, children aren’t the only population at risk. Lead exposure in

<!-- chunk -->

### adults has been linked to severe depression and schizophrenia. One factory that

<!-- chunk -->

### produced tetraethyl lead was known as the “House of Butterflies,” because so

<!-- chunk -->

### many workers had hallucinations.

<!-- chunk -->

### Lead exposure has also been linked to depression, irritability, interpersonal

<!-- chunk -->

### conflict, fatigue, anger, tension, and even decreased sex drive.

<!-- chunk -->

### And it has been linked to degenerative changes in the brain on MRI. In fact,

<!-- chunk -->

### evidence shows that much of what we think of as “normal” age-related decline

<!-- chunk -->

### in mental and cognitive function is actually due to chronic lead toxicity and the

<!-- chunk -->

### resultant loss of brain function.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### soil and water, as well as from our own bones, where it is stored.

<!-- chunk -->

### Blood lead levels were measured in a nationally representative sample of

<!-- chunk -->

### 13,946 adult participants of the Third National Health and Nutrition

<!-- chunk -->

### Examination Survey (NHANES III), recruited in 1988 to 1994 and followed for

<!-- chunk -->

### up to twelve years to track what diseases people developed and why they died.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### strokes, and death.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### increased by 55 percent, risk of heart attacks increased by 151 percent, and risk

<!-- chunk -->

### of stroke increased by 89 percent.

### What was even more remarkable is that it is estimated that nearly

<!-- chunk -->

### percent of all Americans have toxic levels of lead high enough to cause these

<!-- chunk -->

### problems.

# What Do Neurotransmitters Do?

### Neurotransmitters are the messenger molecules produced by nerve cells to

<!-- chunk -->

### communicate and control almost every function of your body. This is the way

<!-- chunk -->

### your brain “talks.” Each nerve cell releases different neurotransmitters, which

<!-- chunk -->

### then have to find a spot, or “receptor,” on another cell, bind to it, and

<!-- chunk -->

### communicate instructions for that cell. Once it is released, it can be recycled or

<!-- chunk -->

### broken down and destroyed.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### which psychiatry is largely based—focus on mimicking or increasing the effects

<!-- chunk -->

### of these neurotransmitters in some way that works against the body’s natural

<!-- chunk -->

### processes.

<!-- chunk -->

### For example, antidepressants typically increase the availability of serotonin

<!-- chunk -->

### (the happy mood molecule) or norepinephrine (a stimulating and energy-giving

<!-- chunk -->

### neurotransmitter); stimulants increase dopamine effects (the pleasure and reward

<!-- chunk -->

### neurotransmitter that is responsible for attention and focus); Alzheimer’s drugs

<!-- chunk -->

### increase acetylcholine (which is responsible for memory and focus); and anxiety

<!-- chunk -->

### drugs increase GABA (which puts the brakes on your excitatory

<!-- chunk -->

### neurotransmitters).

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

## A New Model of Nutrition: Turning “Minimum Daily

<!-- chunk -->

## Requirements” Upside Down

<!-- chunk -->

### Doctors learn that vitamins are important to prevent deficiency diseases

<!-- chunk -->

### (diseases caused by a lack of specific vitamins or minerals) like scurvy or

<!-- chunk -->

### rickets. Too little vitamin C and you get scurvy. Too little vitamin D and you get

<!-- chunk -->

### rickets. That’s it. That is the extent of our nutritional training.

<!-- chunk -->

### However, there is a new concept emerging. Having enough of a nutrient to

<!-- chunk -->

### prevent one of these deficiency diseases, but not enough to optimize cellular

<!-- chunk -->

### function, will lead to “long-latency” deficiency diseases (diseases that take a

<!-- chunk -->

### long time to manifest themselves) like heart disease, cancer, depression,

<!-- chunk -->

### schizophrenia, attention-deficit disorder, or Alzheimer’s disease.

<!-- chunk -->

### For example, if you are severely deficient in folic acid, you will have

<!-- chunk -->

### anemia after a few months, or have a baby with birth defects. This is a

<!-- chunk -->

### deficiency disease. But if you don’t have enough folic acid for optimal function

<!-- chunk -->

### over thirty to forty years, you will double your risk of Alzheimer’s disease.


<!-- chunk -->

### This is a long-latency deficiency disease. There are dozens of examples like

<!-- chunk -->

### this of diseases caused by long-term nutrient deficiency.

<!-- chunk -->

### Let’s examine our old model of nutrition, and how we need a radically

<!-- chunk -->

### different view if we are to effectively address, not only our broken brains but

<!-- chunk -->

### also all chronic illness.

<!-- chunk -->

### The old model of nutrition is based on providing the minimum amount of

<!-- chunk -->

### nutrients, vitamins, and minerals to prevent deficiency diseases. The questions

<!-- chunk -->

### being asked are: how much vitamin C is needed to prevent scurvy? How much

<!-- chunk -->

### thiamine is needed to prevent beriberi? How much niacin is needed to prevent

<!-- chunk -->

### pellagra? How much vitamin D is needed to prevent rickets?

<!-- chunk -->

### The answer is not very much.

<!-- chunk -->

### Understanding the role of vitamins and minerals in health this way is based

<!-- chunk -->

### on the concept that individual nutrients have one physiological role: to prevent

<!-- chunk -->

### the deficiency diseases. Vitamin C prevents scurvy. Vitamin D prevents rickets.

<!-- chunk -->

### That’s it. As long as you don’t have those problems, you are getting enough of

<!-- chunk -->

### the vitamins and minerals you need.

<!-- chunk -->

### The current dietary reference intakes (DRIs), or the amount of nutrients we

<!-- chunk -->

### are told is safe and desirable by the government, are based on this outdated

<!-- chunk -->

### concept. Oddly, the USDA, or United States Department of Agriculture, not the

<!-- chunk -->

### Health and Human Services Department, sets the DRIs. Unfortunately, our

<!-- chunk -->

### nutritional needs, agricultural policy, and government subsidies of our industrial

<!-- chunk -->

### food supply compete with each other. The subsidies are primarily for corn and

<!-- chunk -->

### soybeans, which are used to make high-fructose corn syrup, trans fats, and most

<!-- chunk -->

### of the raw materials for the fast food, junk food, and processed food industry.

<!-- chunk -->

### Policy often overrides science in the end.

<!-- chunk -->

### The thinking that led us to believe the DRIs are suitable recommendations

<!-- chunk -->

### for what we need to operate optimally is no longer scientifically sound. Since the

<!-- chunk -->

### human genome has been deciphered, we now recognize that there is vast

<!-- chunk -->

### biochemical variability within the population.

<!-- chunk -->

### Do you snore? Are you tired most of the day? Do you have trouble focusing,

<!-- chunk -->

### concentrating, and feel depressed? Do you nod off when you sit down to watch

<!-- chunk -->

### TV or read, or worse when you are driving? You could be one of the 18 million

<!-- chunk -->

### people (80 percent of whom are not diagnosed


<!-- chunk -->

### ) who have sleep apnea, a

<!-- chunk -->

### condition where your airway closes off periodically at night, interrupting your

<!-- chunk -->

### sleep as well as leading to high blood pressure, weight gain, and even heart

<!-- chunk -->

### failure. If you think you may have this problem, ask your doctor about testing

<!-- chunk -->

### and treatment. It could save your life.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

# What Is Systemic (Whole-Body) Inflammation? The

# Smoldering Fire Within

<!-- chunk -->

### Most of us are familiar with inflammation. Classic signs are pain, swelling,

<!-- chunk -->

### redness, and heat. Think about a bad sore throat, a swollen knee, or an infected

<!-- chunk -->

### fingernail. In each case, the part of your body that’s affected is inflamed.

<!-- chunk -->

### Inflammation is part of the body’s natural defense system against infection,

<!-- chunk -->

### irritation, toxins, and foreign molecules. When your body detects problems like

<!-- chunk -->

### these, a cascade of events occurs in which white blood cells and chemicals called

<!-- chunk -->

### cytokines (see the text box on page 175 to learn more about these important

<!-- chunk -->

### chemicals) mobilize to protect you from foreign invaders.

<!-- chunk -->

### In this capacity, inflammation is a good thing. It fights foreign invaders of

<!-- chunk -->

### all types.

<!-- chunk -->

### However, when the natural balance of your immune system (which

<!-- chunk -->

### produces just enough inflammation to keep infections, allergens, toxins, or other

<!-- chunk -->

### stressors under control) is disrupted, the immune system shifts into a chronic

<!-- chunk -->

### state of alarm, spreading a smoldering fire of inflammation throughout the body.

<!-- chunk -->

### In essence, the part of your immune system that is designed to protect you

<!-- chunk -->

### from foreign invaders starts attacking the cells and tissues of your own body.

<!-- chunk -->

### When this happens it can create major problems.

<!-- chunk -->

### This fire in the heart causes heart disease, in our fat cells causes obesity, in

<!-- chunk -->

### the whole body causes cancer, in the eyes causes blindness, and, when this fire

<!-- chunk -->

### spreads to your brain, it can cause depression, dementia, autism, ADHD,

<!-- chunk -->

### Alzheimer’s, forgetfulness, and a host of other problems.

<!-- chunk -->

### This inflammatory process may go awry, not only in individuals with

<!-- chunk -->

### inflammatory diseases but in otherwise healthy people whose lifestyles and/or

<!-- chunk -->

### environments expose them to substances the body perceives as irritants, such as

<!-- chunk -->

### low-grade infections from gum disease, food allergens, toxins, and even

<!-- chunk -->

### inflammatory foods such as sugar and animal fat. (You will learn more about

<!-- chunk -->

### each of these specific causes of inflammation later in the chapter.)

<!-- chunk -->

### While inflammation is sometimes obvious, such as when an injured area

<!-- chunk -->

### becomes swollen, red, and warm to the touch, science is teaching us that

<!-- chunk -->

### inflammation can occur silently and insidiously, without any symptoms.

<!-- chunk -->

### To understand how profound inflammation can be to brain health, I want to

<!-- chunk -->

### look at three conditions that may be caused by inflammation: autism, depression,

<!-- chunk -->

### and Alzheimer’s. If we understand how inflammation plays a role in these

<!-- chunk -->

### conditions, we will have an opportunity to treat all problems of brain function in

<!-- chunk -->

### a radically different way.

<!-- chunk -->

### Most psychiatric and neurological problems, in some way, are just the brain

<!-- chunk -->

### on fire.

<!-- chunk -->

### CYTOKINES:

<!-- chunk -->

### THE MESSENGER MOLECULES OF YOUR IMMUNE SYSTEM

<!-- chunk -->

### Cytokines are a class of proteins that are the “language” of your

<!-- chunk -->

### immune system, much in the way neurotransmitters are the “language” of

<!-- chunk -->

### your nervous system, and hormones are the “language” of your endocrine

<!-- chunk -->

### system or hormone-secreting glands.

<!-- chunk -->

### These chemicals can either promote or reduce inflammation. They are

<!-- chunk -->

### the main communication system that controls inflammation and directs

<!-- chunk -->

### your immune system to heal.

<!-- chunk -->

### When triggered by toxins, infections, allergens, stress, a bad diet, or a

<!-- chunk -->

### sedentary lifestyle, cytokines run out of control starting fires all over the

<!-- chunk -->

### body and brain. There are 400,000 scientific studies on the role of these

<!-- chunk -->

### immune messengers in almost every disease. Inflammation does not

<!-- chunk -->

### respect the artificial boundaries of medical specialties.

<!-- chunk -->

### In fact, when it comes to chronic illnesses—whether physical or mental

<!-- chunk -->

### — everywhere we look, there they are. Dementia, depression, ADHD,

<!-- chunk -->

### autism, chronic fatigue, obesity, heart disease, cancer, and, of course,

<!-- chunk -->

### allergic and autoimmune diseases are all related to elevated levels of

<!-- chunk -->

### cytokines and systemic inflammation. They can cause problems in every

<!-- chunk -->

### organ, in every part of the body.

<!-- chunk -->

### The most startling and convincing story comes from the world of autism. As

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### our brain. The same things happen in depression, Alzheimer’s, or almost any

<!-- chunk -->

### psychiatric or neurological problem.

<!-- chunk -->

### illnesses become apparent. Autism and Alzheimer’s are almost the same disease

<!-- chunk -->

### showing up at the opposite end of the age spectrum—the metabolism,

<!-- chunk -->

### biochemistry, and causes all map over one another.

<!-- chunk -->

### Harvard Medical School, has put together a remarkable story of autism, which is

<!-- chunk -->

### like a hologram through which we can see the systemic nature of most illness.

<!-- chunk -->

### brain?”


<!-- chunk -->

### will change forever our thinking about mental and brain illness.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### She noticed their brains were bigger than children who did not have autism.


<!-- chunk -->

### The

<!-- chunk -->

### question that remained was why.

<!-- chunk -->

### That’s where Dr. Diana Vargas and her group from Johns Hopkins came in.

<!-- chunk -->

### They examined the brains on autopsy of eleven autistic children who had died.


<!-- chunk -->

### They also looked at the spinal fluid of living autistic children. By examining and

<!-- chunk -->

### comparing these factors, they proved that these children’s brains were swollen

<!-- chunk -->

### and inflamed, like a swollen ankle!

<!-- chunk -->

### This brought up another question: why were their brains inflamed to begin

<!-- chunk -->

### with?

<!-- chunk -->

### The short answer is allergens, toxins, infections, and nutritional

<!-- chunk -->

### deficiencies.

<!-- chunk -->

### But where do problems like these come from and how do they affect the

<!-- chunk -->

### brain? Are they in the brain to begin with? Well, many times they may not be.

<!-- chunk -->

### It has long been known that children with autism not only have misfiring

<!-- chunk -->

### and wiring of their brain, but that 95 percent of autistic children have

<!-- chunk -->

### gastrointestinal problems and swollen bellies. It has also been noted that autistic

<!-- chunk -->

### children have frequent infections and allergies, and have often had multiple

### courses of antibiotics. And according to the MIND Institute at the University of

<!-- chunk -->

### California at Davis, more than 70 percent of children on the autistic spectrum

<!-- chunk -->

### they have nothing to do with why autistic children’s brains are not working

### properly or why their brains are swollen and inflamed.

### But according to Dr. Herbert, the opposite seems to be true. These gut,

<!-- chunk -->

### immune, and toxicity problems are integrally related to and often the cause of

<!-- chunk -->

### what happens in the brain. In fact, she suggests that autism is really a systemic

<!-- chunk -->

### metabolic disorder that changes brain function. The brain and body function as a

<!-- chunk -->

### whole system. And multiple chronic, insidious triggers can throw the brain into

<!-- chunk -->

### chaos.

<!-- chunk -->

### As you will learn in chapter 9 when I discuss the gut, more than 60 percent

<!-- chunk -->

### of the immune system is in the digestive tract. When that key system in the body

<!-- chunk -->

### is thrown out of balance, your immune system is triggered and widespread

<!-- chunk -->

### systemic inflammation can often result.

<!-- chunk -->

### We insult our digestive tract every day. We do everything to harm it and

<!-- chunk -->

### hardly anything to help it work as it was designed. We eat food low in fiber, high

### in sugar, and full of antibiotics, pesticides, and hormones; we drink alcohol and

<!-- chunk -->

### caffeine; we take antibiotics, acid-blocking medication, anti-inflammatory drugs,

### hormones, and steroids; we are under constant stress; and we are exposed to

### thousands of environmental toxins, all of which damage the gut.

### system reacts to all the foreign proteins in food and all the myriad of bugs and

### gets “angry” and inflamed.

### swollen bellies), then spreads to the brain, it can literally lead to a swollen brain.

### And the effects can be disastrous.

<!-- chunk -->

### Imagine the extraordinary beauty and dance of the brain where everything

### is exquisitely regulated. The timing and coordination of nerve-cell firing and the

### our sensory inputs must let in only the information we need. The activity of the

### brain must be exquisitely synchronized for us to be awake, alert, receptive,

### person. In the children discussed above, the result of this inflammation is autism.

### In you, it may be anything from a bad mood to dementia to hyperactivity and

### difficulty focusing.

### Whatever the case, at the end of the day we are all suffering from swollen

### brains.

### we need to look for answers.

### problem.

### Is Depression a Systemic Inflammatory Disease?

<!-- chunk -->

### How can exercise and fish oil often be a more effective treatment for

<!-- chunk -->

### depression than antidepressants? Could it be because they are both potent anti-

<!-- chunk -->

### inflammatories? Could it be that depression is a low-grade inflammatory disease

<!-- chunk -->

### of the brain?


<!-- chunk -->

### Let’s look at the evidence.


<!-- chunk -->

## 1. Proinflammatory cytokines IL-1, IL-6, and TNF a (molecular messengers

<!-- chunk -->

### that set off the inflammatory response) and bacterial toxins (produced in

<!-- chunk -->

### our gut for reasons we will explore in chapter 9) produce symptoms of

<!-- chunk -->

### depression and anxiety.

<!-- chunk -->

## 2. Cytokines overactivate the HPA (hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal) axis

<!-- chunk -->

### (the stress response), just as we find in depressed patients.

<!-- chunk -->

## 3. Cytokines increase the function of an enzyme (IDO) that breaks down

<!-- chunk -->

### tryptophan, leading to less serotonin in the brain.


<!-- chunk -->

## 4. The immune system is overactive in severe depression, producing brain


<!-- chunk -->

## 5. Using immune therapy like interferon (a cytokine) for diseases like

<!-- chunk -->

### hepatitis C or multiple sclerosis triggers depression.

<!-- chunk -->

## 6. Depression is more common in inflammatory diseases like autoimmune

<!-- chunk -->

### disease and heart disease.

<!-- chunk -->

### As compelling as these pieces of information are, they are not the only

<!-- chunk -->

### indications that depression is caused by an inflamed brain.

<!-- chunk -->

### Researchers from the Free University of Berlin discovered a new virus

<!-- chunk -->

### called Bornavirus found in the limbic system (or emotional center) of the brain

<!-- chunk -->

### in 30 percent of the population. One in six people who carry the virus have

<!-- chunk -->

### depression and can be cured by treatment with short-term anti-viral medication.

<!-- chunk -->

### Think about it: a virus can cause depression and treating the virus can cure, not

<!-- chunk -->

### just reduce the symptoms of, depression. Even the best antidepressant drugs

<!-- chunk -->

### don’t cure depression.


<!-- chunk -->

### And there is more evidence that inflammation can cause depression. A new

<!-- chunk -->

### technique called vagal nerve stimulation is very helpful in depression.


<!-- chunk -->

### The

<!-- chunk -->

### vagus nerve is your calming, relaxation nerve. When you take a deep breath,

<!-- chunk -->

### meditate, or do yoga, the nerve is activated and it releases acetylcholine, which

<!-- chunk -->

### reduces the production of inflammatory cytokines.

<!-- chunk -->

### There may be many reasons deep breathing and relaxation work, but

<!-- chunk -->

### certainly one of them is the fact that inflammation is reduced.

<!-- chunk -->

### We also know that omega-3 fats help depression and produce remission.


<!-- chunk -->

### They work through lowering inflammation, and also through their effects on cell

<!-- chunk -->

### membranes and communication.

<!-- chunk -->

### Similarly, we know that exercise is an anti-inflammatory and works better

<!-- chunk -->

### than Prozac in treating depression.


<!-- chunk -->

### Another example comes out of Harvard. A group of researchers there

<!-- chunk -->

### discovered an increased number of “white matter lesions” or little white spots in

<!-- chunk -->

### the brain that are seen in autoimmune diseases like multiple sclerosis in

<!-- chunk -->

### depressed patients. This correlated with low levels of folate, which caused high

<!-- chunk -->

### levels of homocysteine, a molecule that causes inflammation in the brain.


<!-- chunk -->

### So

<!-- chunk -->

### being vitamin-deficient produces toxic molecules that inflame the brain and

<!-- chunk -->

### cause depression.

<!-- chunk -->

### Of course, we must ask, “What came first, the chicken or the egg? Does

<!-- chunk -->

### depression cause inflammation or inflammation cause depression?”

<!-- chunk -->

### The answer is yes. It is a vicious cycle. Inflammation leads to depression,

<!-- chunk -->

### which leads to more inflammation.

<!-- chunk -->

### The message is that to adequately treat depression we must look for, find,

<!-- chunk -->

### and eliminate the causes of inflammation and then help the body create balance

<!-- chunk -->

### in the immune system, turning off this vicious cycle.

<!-- chunk -->

### All of the things that create inflammation not only cause depression but also

<!-- chunk -->

### anxiety, obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), and bipolar disease. Of course,

<!-- chunk -->

### we must remember that these are just names of collections of symptoms we give

<!-- chunk -->

### people. The causes may be very different from person to person. But within the

<!-- chunk -->

### seven keys we can find the causes, and we must treat all of them for people to

<!-- chunk -->

### heal.

<!-- chunk -->

### Looked at as a whole, the pieces of the scientific puzzle make sense. In a

<!-- chunk -->

### separate but connected example, there is a form of OCD that is well documented

<!-- chunk -->

### in children called PANDAS (Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders

<!-- chunk -->

### Associated with Streptococcal Infections). This condition causes children to

<!-- chunk -->

### suffer from the strange obsessions and compulsions “called” OCD—anything

<!-- chunk -->

### from repeatedly washing hands, or opening and closing doors, to counting

<!-- chunk -->

### objects, to involuntary movements. It is triggered by an infection with

<!-- chunk -->

### streptococcus.


<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### inflammation in the brain. Treat the bacteria with antibiotics, inflammation in the

<!-- chunk -->

### brain is reduced, and the OCD goes away.

<!-- chunk -->

### Why aren’t we looking at models like this one as a way to treat other “brain

<!-- chunk -->

### disorders”? Why do we insist on viewing them as “psychiatric problems” instead

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### delayed.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### bread on Monday and be depressed on Wednesday, or have a piece of cheese

<!-- chunk -->

### today and get a migraine tomorrow. You never make the connection, because

<!-- chunk -->

### you don’t even realize food can have this kind of impact on you.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

## The Brain-Gut Connection:

<!-- chunk -->

## Your Gut Is Your Second Brain

<!-- chunk -->

### Dr. Michael Gershon, of Columbia University, has called the gut the “second

<!-- chunk -->

### brain.” In fact, your gut has a mind of its own, literally. While it is connected to

<!-- chunk -->

### the brain through an extensive network of wiring and communication systems, it

<!-- chunk -->

### is also the only “organ” besides the brain that has its own nervous system.

<!-- chunk -->

### We call it the ENS, or enteric (or gut) nervous system, as opposed to the

<!-- chunk -->

### CNS, or central nervous system. The small intestine alone has as many neurons

<!-- chunk -->

### as the spinal cord. Ninety-five percent of the body’s serotonin (remember, that’s

<!-- chunk -->

### the happy mood chemical) is produced by the gut nerve cells, and every class of

<!-- chunk -->

### neurotransmitters found in the brain is also found in the gut.

<!-- chunk -->

### The question is how does this nervous system below interact with the one

<!-- chunk -->

### above?

<!-- chunk -->

### The gut brain actually comes from the same embryonic tissue as the “brain”

<!-- chunk -->

### brain. And it is still connected via the autonomic nervous system— the

<!-- chunk -->

### sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves.

<!-- chunk -->

### Acting completely independently, it has a number of important jobs: it

<!-- chunk -->

### keeps everything moving in the right direction from the top down by

<!-- chunk -->

### coordinating the contraction of muscle cells; it triggers the gut hormones and

<!-- chunk -->

### enzymes to be released from cells to promote digestion; it helps keep the blood

<!-- chunk -->

### flowing so that when you absorb your food it can get to where it needs to go, and

<!-- chunk -->

### it controls the immune and inflammatory cells in the gut.


<!-- chunk -->

### All that happens in the background and is communicated back up to your

<!-- chunk -->

### brain via the autonomic nervous system. Think of it as two independent, but

<!-- chunk -->

### interdependent, businesses that must coordinate and communicate but can act

<!-- chunk -->

### independently.

<!-- chunk -->

### But how does this interaction affect us?

<!-- chunk -->

### Nearly everyone has experienced “butterflies” in the stomach, or had

<!-- chunk -->

### diarrhea under acute stress, or, worse, became incontinent in life-threatening

<!-- chunk -->

### situations. Clearly, we can have a “nervous” stomach because of our thoughts

<!-- chunk -->

### and feelings and external events. But can we have a “nervous” brain (or a

<!-- chunk -->

### depressed or hyperactive or autistic or demented brain) because of mischief

<!-- chunk -->

### originating in the gut—specifically due to problems with digesting food, the gut

<!-- chunk -->

### immune system, or signals that go haywire on the way from our gut-brain, or

<!-- chunk -->

### ENS, to our “brain” brain?

<!-- chunk -->

### In medical training, most doctors think pejoratively of people with

<!-- chunk -->

### “functional bowel” disorders. Doctors see nothing with the tools they use—

<!-- chunk -->

### scopes, X-rays, and scans. No tumors, ulcers, or blockages. Nothing “real.” So

<!-- chunk -->

### these patients are just neurotic people with emotionally triggered symptoms.

<!-- chunk -->

### Right?

<!-- chunk -->

### The evidence is directing us otherwise.

<!-- chunk -->

### The suffering for millions is real. So the question becomes, are these tens of

<!-- chunk -->

### millions of Americans “crazy,” with “psychosomatic symptoms” that lead them

<!-- chunk -->

### to be irritable, anxious, depressed, and obsessed with their digestive system? Or

<!-- chunk -->

### are we missing something?

<!-- chunk -->

### Thankfully, new science is shedding light on this topic.

<!-- chunk -->

### Over the years I have seen emotional, psychiatric, and behavioral symptoms

<!-- chunk -->

### triggered by problems in the gut. One of my patients was a thirty-year-old

<!-- chunk -->

### executive who would experience anxiety and insomnia whenever his irritable

<!-- chunk -->

### bowel would act up. Another was a little boy who would have explosive bouts of

<!-- chunk -->

### anger whenever his stomach was a little “swollen” with gas. Yet another was a

<!-- chunk -->

### woman who found herself free of lifelong depression after a course of antibiotics

<!-- chunk -->

### (metronidazole) we used to clear out bad bacteria from her gut.

<!-- chunk -->

### When psychiatric symptoms are “coincidentally” cleared up with

<!-- chunk -->

### antibiotics, that gets my attention.


<!-- chunk -->

### How could this happen? An autistic boy I

<!-- chunk -->

### treated actually began to speak after changing his diet and eliminating gluten and

<!-- chunk -->

### dairy, which altered the “information” that went into his gut.

<!-- chunk -->

### These remarkable stories are all evidence of the intimate connection

<!-- chunk -->

### between your gut and your brain.

<!-- chunk -->

### Doctors often blame a patient’s psychiatric problems for their gut

<!-- chunk -->

### symptoms. They are “psychosomatic” illnesses created in the brain of people

<!-- chunk -->

### whose anxieties get the best of them.

<!-- chunk -->

### But perhaps, very often, it just may be the other way around. Mischief in

<!-- chunk -->

### the gut causes disturbance in the brain. Fix the gut, and mood, behavior, and

<!-- chunk -->

### cognition all improve.

<!-- chunk -->

### Many different factors affect gut—and brain—health:

<!-- chunk -->

### Unfriendly bacteria in the gut and other bugs like yeast that produce brain

<!-- chunk -->

### toxins.

<!-- chunk -->

### Fermentation of starches from your diet, which produce gas and toxic

<!-- chunk -->

### levels of ammonia.

<!-- chunk -->

### Odd, partially digested food proteins that interfere with normal brain

<!-- chunk -->

### operations.

<!-- chunk -->

### Activation of the immune system because of digestive imbalances that

<!-- chunk -->

### damage the protective barrier, which normally keeps the outside world

<!-- chunk -->

### from entering through the gut.

<!-- chunk -->

### Why are millions of us having all these gut problems?

<!-- chunk -->

### The answer is that we are not very kind to our gut. We eat a SAD diet

<!-- chunk -->

### (Standard American Diet), which is low in fiber and nutrients and rich in sugar,

<!-- chunk -->

### additives, and chemicals, which changes the ecosystem of our gut.

<!-- chunk -->

### We are under chronic stress, which damages the normal intestinal barrier

<!-- chunk -->

### and affects the ENS.

<!-- chunk -->

### Our drug culture pushes antibiotics, anti-inflammatories, aspirin, steroids,

<!-- chunk -->

### and acid-blocking medications that all disrupt our gut’s ability to stay in balance

<!-- chunk -->

### and do its job.

<!-- chunk -->

### And we are exposed to toxins such as mercury, which damage our normal

<!-- chunk -->

### gut function.

<!-- chunk -->

### All in all, we live in dangerous digestive times.

<!-- chunk -->

### An article in the Journal of the American Medical Association by Dr. Henry

<!-- chunk -->

### Lin


<!-- chunk -->

### mapped out a new way of thinking about irritable bowel and the

<!-- chunk -->

### psychological symptoms seen in irritable bowel patients.

<!-- chunk -->

### He turns the current view on its head by saying that bacterial mischief in the

<!-- chunk -->

### small intestine (from bacteria that migrate up from the large intestine into a

<!-- chunk -->

### normally sterile territory) triggers an immune and nervous system response that

<!-- chunk -->

### sends messages back to the brain, which lead to insomnia,


<!-- chunk -->

### “sickness behavior,”

<!-- chunk -->

### anxiety, depression,


<!-- chunk -->

### and impaired cognitive function.


<!-- chunk -->

### The gut immune system

<!-- chunk -->

### “speaks” to the brain, sending messages of inflammation, which increases levels

<!-- chunk -->

### of CRF (corticotropin releasing factor) in the hypothalamus (which, in turn,

<!-- chunk -->

### increases stress hormones like cortisol),


<!-- chunk -->

### and changes neurotransmitter levels.


<!-- chunk -->

### Your gut is talking to your brain. And when these bacteria are involved, the

<!-- chunk -->

### communication isn’t good.

<!-- chunk -->

### So, bottom line—little bacteria in our gut start a cascade of immune and

<!-- chunk -->

### neurological events that stop our brain from doing what it was designed to do

<!-- chunk -->

### and this creates poor connections and communication all around.

<!-- chunk -->

### This is one of the major ways your gut sends signals of ill health to your

<!-- chunk -->

### brain that can manifest themselves as any type of broken brain and many other

<!-- chunk -->

### illnesses.

<!-- chunk -->

### I want to discuss how this happens. Let me start by telling you the story of

<!-- chunk -->

### one of my patients, who suffered from this problem.

## Bugged Out: How Bugs in Your Brain Make You Crazy

<!-- chunk -->

### The most remarkable story of how bugs in the gut can affect your brain is

<!-- chunk -->

### from a woman who came to see me with the typical “whole list” of problems

<!-- chunk -->

### (which is why I call myself a “whole-listic” doctor).

<!-- chunk -->

### Most of her problems started in her gut—she had the usual diagnoses of

<!-- chunk -->

### irritable bowel syndrome with terrible bloating after meals as well as acid

<!-- chunk -->

### reflux, and she also had an autoimmune disease with joint pains and lots of

<!-- chunk -->

### inflammatory symptoms such as allergies and rashes.

<!-- chunk -->

### She also had metabolic syndrome, or prediabetes, thyroid problems, and

<!-- chunk -->

### chronic stress.

<!-- chunk -->

### In addition to all these problems, she also suffered from debilitating

<!-- chunk -->

### obsessive-compulsive disorder. She was an educated, otherwise well-balanced

<!-- chunk -->

### human being, and there was nothing odd about her on the surface. But she could

<!-- chunk -->

### not pick up anything off her floor or clean or move anything in her house

<!-- chunk -->

### because of this weird obsession— for years!

<!-- chunk -->

### In the ten years before she came to see me, she had become increasingly

<!-- chunk -->

### withdrawn because of her severe fatigue and her frustration and exhaustion from

<!-- chunk -->

### these quirky behaviors.

<!-- chunk -->

### Actually she had been given many “diagnoses” over the years by many

<!-- chunk -->

### different doctors, including depression, anxiety, OCD, and sleep disorder. She

<!-- chunk -->

### also had severe fatigue for many years.

<!-- chunk -->

### As a result, she took many drug cocktails over the years, including Ritalin

<!-- chunk -->

### and Dexedrine—or speed. When I first saw her she was on Provigil (a new drug

<!-- chunk -->

### to wake up the brain), and Depakote, a seizure drug given to OCD and bipolar

<!-- chunk -->

### patients, as well as two antidepressants, Celexa and Wellbutrin. She was also on

<!-- chunk -->

### a highly controlled new drug for sleep called Xyrem (which was the knockout

<!-- chunk -->

### date rape drug, or GHB). This was quite a collection of mood stabilizers,

<!-- chunk -->

### uppers, and downers—this woman was a walking pharmacy.

<!-- chunk -->

### We found she was allergic to gluten and dairy and she was making very odd

<!-- chunk -->

### peptides (little proteins) because of poor digestion. These are morphinelike

<!-- chunk -->

### proteins that result from incomplete digestion of casein (from dairy) and gluten

<!-- chunk -->

### (from wheat), which have been linked to many psychiatric disorders, especially

<!-- chunk -->

### autism and ADHD.


<!-- chunk -->

### She also had vitamin D and magnesium deficiency, which can contribute, as

<!-- chunk -->

### you learned in chapter 6, to depression and anxiety.

<!-- chunk -->

### When we looked at her gut environment with a stool analysis, we found

<!-- chunk -->

### there weren’t any of the normal healthy bacteria growing, her gut lining was

<!-- chunk -->

### inflamed, and some strangers had taken up residence in her gut, including yeasts

<!-- chunk -->

### and odd bacteria.

<!-- chunk -->

### A gut is a veritable ecosystem—like a rain forest. There are over five

<!-- chunk -->

### hundred species of bacteria living there weighing in at a whopping three pounds.

<!-- chunk -->

### There is more bacterial DNA in your body than human DNA. All of them need to

<!-- chunk -->

### be in balance and in the right place (mostly in your large intestine) for your gut

<!-- chunk -->

### to function properly.

<!-- chunk -->

### There are good bugs and bad bugs. The good bugs help digest your food,

<!-- chunk -->

### produce vitamins, control inflammation, boost immune function, and more. The

<!-- chunk -->

### bad bugs produce toxins, ferment starches leading to bloating and gas, and

<!-- chunk -->

### sometimes move into areas of the bowel like the stomach and small intestines

<!-- chunk -->

### where they create terrible mischief. We generally want to get rid of the bad bugs

<!-- chunk -->

### and add more good bugs or probiotics to keep the gut healthy.

<!-- chunk -->

### As part of this woman’s gut cleanup, I gave her a new treatment pioneered

<!-- chunk -->

### by Dr. Mark Pimentel, of the University of California at the Los Angeles School

<!-- chunk -->

### of Medicine.


<!-- chunk -->

### A nonabsorbed antibiotic called Xifaxin clears out abnormal

<!-- chunk -->

### bacteria in the small bowel. I expected her bloating and even some of her

<!-- chunk -->

### inflammatory symptoms to clear up by fixing her gut. But I was surprised by

<!-- chunk -->

### what she told me after she took the antibiotic.

<!-- chunk -->

### Overnight her OCD disappeared; after years of unsuccessful treatment with

<!-- chunk -->

### psychotherapy and psychiatric medications, she was suddenly able to clean her

<!-- chunk -->

### entire house and pick up everything off the floor. The lights in her brain had

<!-- chunk -->

### come on for the first time in ten years.

<!-- chunk -->

### A high level of ammonia in her blood caused her OCD. Ammonia is a

<!-- chunk -->

### neurotoxin that excites and damages brain cells and the mitochondria (the site of

<!-- chunk -->

### energy production in all cells—see chapter 11 for more information). Bacteria in

<!-- chunk -->

### the gut produces ammonia, and when the liver can’t detoxify it, or there is just

<!-- chunk -->

### too much, it causes brain damage.

<!-- chunk -->

### Every physician knows this because since the 1960s doctors have been

<!-- chunk -->

### treating a condition known as “hepatic encephalopathy,”


<!-- chunk -->

### a form of temporary

<!-- chunk -->

### insanity common in patients with liver failure. The brain dysfunction results from

<!-- chunk -->

### too much ammonia and is cured by clearing out the ammonia-producing

<!-- chunk -->

### bacteria in the gut with antibiotics. So this idea shouldn’t seem strange to most

<!-- chunk -->

### doctors.

<!-- chunk -->

### But it occurs in many patients—not just those with liver failure.

<!-- chunk -->

### When we rechecked her ammonia level after treatment, it had returned to

<!-- chunk -->

### normal. After a few months, the bacteria came back, and so did her OCD

<!-- chunk -->

### symptoms, and once again treating the bacteria cured her OCD. The link was

<!-- chunk -->

### clear.

<!-- chunk -->

### And this is just one of many ways abnormal gut bacteria can affect your

<!-- chunk -->

### thoughts and cognitive function.

<!-- chunk -->

### In fact, Pimentel talks about seeing common symptoms like brain fog and

<!-- chunk -->

### fatigue in patients with irritable bowel syndrome that clear up when the toxic

<!-- chunk -->

### bacteria are cleaned up using the treatment he created. A bloated belly leads to a

<!-- chunk -->

### bloated brain. The symptoms can vary from OCD to depression to anxiety to

<!-- chunk -->

### autism or even psychosis.

<!-- chunk -->

### So what else do we know about how bugs down below affect command

<!-- chunk -->

### central up on top?

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

## Food Allergies Revisited: More Mischievous Molecules

<!-- chunk -->

### Why do we become sensitive or allergic to foods?

<!-- chunk -->

### In the last chapter we learned that food allergies cause inflammation and that

<!-- chunk -->

### this occurs because of imbalances in the gut. So what sends our gut out of

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### inflammation, overuse of medications, environmental toxins, and the rest—

<!-- chunk -->

### damage the surface of our intestinal lining in the small intestine.

<!-- chunk -->

### tennis court, but it is only one cell layer thick. When this delicate surface is

<!-- chunk -->

### damaged, inflammation spreads throughout the brain and body.

<!-- chunk -->

### as increased intestinal permeability).

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### cells. When it is damaged we cannot digest our food properly. Suddenly we have

<!-- chunk -->

### partially digested food particles from normally innocuous foods “leaking” into

<!-- chunk -->

### our bloodstream through the leaky gut.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### layer of intestinal cells lining our digestive tract, our bodies react by increasing

<!-- chunk -->

### our immune response and generating inflammation. Our immune system,

<!-- chunk -->

### normally used to seeing fully digested foods (like proteins broken down to

<!-- chunk -->

### amino acids, fats broken down to fatty acids, and carbohydrates broken down to

<!-- chunk -->

### simple sugars), suddenly “sees” foreign (meaning partially digested) proteins.

<!-- chunk -->

### So the immune response does what it is designed to do—attack and defend

<!-- chunk -->

### —and this is how we create antibodies and develop IgG allergies to common

<!-- chunk -->

### foods. This is what makes us sick and fat, toxic and inflamed, depressed and

<!-- chunk -->

### anxious, forgetful and foggy.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

# HOW THE BRAIN CONTROLS AUTOMATIC FUNCTIONS

<!-- chunk -->

### Your body governs your stress and relaxation responses through your

<!-- chunk -->

### autonomic nervous system. This system controls all of the automatic

<!-- chunk -->

### functions in your body, and is divided into two parts: the sympathetic

<!-- chunk -->

### nervous system and the parasympathetic nervous system.

<!-- chunk -->

### You don’t have any control over the sympathetic nervous system, and

<!-- chunk -->

### it’s a good thing you don’t. It controls critical bodily functions like your

<!-- chunk -->

### heartbeat and the flow of your blood. Imagine what might happen if you

<!-- chunk -->

### could stop your heartbeat or your blood flow just by thinking about it!

<!-- chunk -->

### However, you do have some control over the parasympathetic nervous

<!-- chunk -->

### system. This part of your body is partially automated, but it is also

<!-- chunk -->

### responsive to your thoughts. For example, the blinking of your eyes is

<!-- chunk -->

### connected to your parasympathetic nervous system. You have some control

<!-- chunk -->

### over it (you can stop blinking your eyes for a while), but not full control

<!-- chunk -->

### over it (keep them open long enough and your eyes will blink).

<!-- chunk -->

### The hypothalamus is the command and control center at the top of this

<!-- chunk -->

### entire chain of events. Its job is to control all “automatic” functions. Stress,

<!-- chunk -->

### as I mentioned above, is controlled by your sympathetic nervous system.

<!-- chunk -->

### You have control over the inputs that cause stress, but you have no control

<!-- chunk -->

### over the response itself. If you perceive stress, your body will react.

<!-- chunk -->

### Relaxation, on the other hand, is something you can control. It is

<!-- chunk -->

### governed by your parasympathetic nervous system, so you can consciously

<!-- chunk -->

### engage “the relaxation response,” as I will discuss below.

<!-- chunk -->

### Chronic stress affects all of your autonomic functions negatively, but

<!-- chunk -->

### relaxation helps balance all them. These functions include:

<!-- chunk -->

## 1. Control of blood pressure and electrolyte balance.

<!-- chunk -->

## 2. Control of energy metabolism and metabolic rate.

<!-- chunk -->

## 3. Regulation of body temperature.

<!-- chunk -->

## 4. Control of reproduction and sleep cycle.

<!-- chunk -->

## 5. Regulation of the stress response (and relaxation response) via

<!-- chunk -->

### autonomic activity coordination.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

# Exposure

<!-- chunk -->

### We do not live in an ideal world. And it is impossible to eliminate exposure

<!-- chunk -->

### to electromagnetic radiation. Debate still rages. The research on harm from EMR

<!-- chunk -->

### is not as extensive as it should be. Yet the absence of evidence is not evidence of

<!-- chunk -->

### absence.

<!-- chunk -->

### Just because we have not proved beyond a doubt that EMR is harmful,

<!-- chunk -->

### neither is there any evidence that it is safe. Until we have clear evidence of

<!-- chunk -->

### safety I recommend erring on the side of caution, rather than waiting for forty

<!-- chunk -->

### years like we did with cigarettes before it was clear there was harm.

<!-- chunk -->

### Here are things you can do to minimize your risk from EMR. Do what you

<!-- chunk -->

### can.

<!-- chunk -->

### Try to minimize your exposure and usage of wireless communication

<!-- chunk -->

### devices, including cell phones, cordless phones, and WiFi devices.

<!-- chunk -->

### Turn your cell phone off when not in use and sleeping. Do not keep it

<!-- chunk -->

### near your head or use it to play games, movies, etc.

<!-- chunk -->

### Try to keep your cell phone at least six to seven inches away from your

<!-- chunk -->

### body while it is on, or when you are talking, texting, or downloading.

<!-- chunk -->

### Use air-tube headsets or speaker mode when talking. Wireless and wired

<!-- chunk -->

### headsets may still conduct radiation.

<!-- chunk -->

### Do not keep your cell phone in your pocket or on your hip all day. The

<!-- chunk -->

### bone marrow in your hip produces 80 percent of the body’s red blood

<!-- chunk -->

### cells and is especially vulnerable to EMR damage. The proximity to your

<!-- chunk -->

### genitals may also affect fertility.

<!-- chunk -->

### Children and pregnant women should avoid talking on cell phones.

<!-- chunk -->

### Replace as many cordless and WiFi items as you can with wired, corded

<!-- chunk -->

### lines (phones, Internet, games, appliances, devices, etc.).

<!-- chunk -->

### Minimize or space out your computer use. Sit as far back from the screen

<!-- chunk -->

### as possible; flat screens are preferable. Use wired Internet connections,

<!-- chunk -->

### not WiFi—especially for laptops.

<!-- chunk -->

### Keep a low-EMR sleep, home, and personal zone.

<!-- chunk -->

### Move your alarm clock radio at least three feet from your head or use

<!-- chunk -->

### battery-powered ones; six feet is the recommended distance from all

<!-- chunk -->

### electronic devices during sleep.

<!-- chunk -->

### Avoid water beds, electric blankets, and metal frames, which attract

<!-- chunk -->

### electromagnetic frequencies.

<!-- chunk -->

### Futons and wood-framed beds are better than metal-coiled mattresses and

<!-- chunk -->

### box springs.

<!-- chunk -->

### When using electric stoves, cook on back burners instead of front as

<!-- chunk -->

### much as possible.

<!-- chunk -->

### Metals attract EMR: keep them away from and off the body.

<!-- chunk -->

### Measure EMR from wireless and wired devices with appropriate meters

<!-- chunk -->

### (see www.safewireless.org).

### To decrease exposures, consider installing EMR filters and preventive

<!-- chunk -->

### technologies to electrical circuits, devices, and appliances. These may

<!-- chunk -->

### help, although human studies are limited.

<!-- chunk -->

### Massage. Learn massage and use it on your partner or friends. And then

<!-- chunk -->

### exchange. Or get a massage as often as you can.

<!-- chunk -->

### Tense and relax. By slowly tensing and relaxing your whole body (all at

<!-- chunk -->

### once or moving progressively from one muscle group to the next—face,

<!-- chunk -->

### neck and shoulders, arms, legs) and then relaxing your whole body (or

<!-- chunk -->

### each muscle group progressively), you will shift the stress response and

<!-- chunk -->

### enter into deep relaxation.

<!-- chunk -->

### Use biofeedback. There are some wonderful computer-simulated tools and

<!-- chunk -->

### devices that can lead you through various mental and physical exercises

<!-- chunk -->

### that will activate the stress response. See the Resources for some options.

<!-- chunk -->

### Just load it into your computer, put three little sensors on your fingers

<!-- chunk -->

### that measure your heart rate variability, and take a journey into deep

<!-- chunk -->

### relaxation.

<!-- chunk -->

### Learn meditation. Mindfulness meditation is a powerful, well-researched

<!-- chunk -->

### tool developed by Buddhists, but now practiced and used all over the

<!-- chunk -->

### world, thanks to the work of Jon Kabat Zinn, Ph.D., of the University of

<!-- chunk -->

### Massachusetts, in many hospitals and medical centers. Read his book

<!-- chunk -->

### Wherever You Go, There You Are to learn basic meditation techniques or

<!-- chunk -->

### attend a local class on meditation.

<!-- chunk -->

### Pray, chant, dance, and celebrate. All these are ancient tools for healing

<!-- chunk -->

### and all help you deeply relax. Just pull down the shades, turn on the

<!-- chunk -->

### music, and dance in your living room.

<!-- chunk -->

### Practice tai qi quan or qi gong. These are ancient, energy-balancing tools

<!-- chunk -->

### that can help restore your health and calm your nervous system.

<!-- chunk -->

### Writing away stress. Journaling is a well studied and powerful tool to help

<!-- chunk -->

### improve mood and become more intimate with yourself. Studies show

<!-- chunk -->

### how it boosts immunity and improves mood.


<!-- chunk -->

### Daily journaling for twenty minutes can be helpful.

<!-- chunk -->

### You can also try this well-researched tool, which can create immediate

<!-- chunk -->

### benefits: Set aside twenty minutes four days a week to write in your journal.

<!-- chunk -->

### Write nonstop about the most upsetting or traumatic experience of your life.

<!-- chunk -->

### Don’t worry about spelling or grammar. Write about all your emotions and

<!-- chunk -->

### thoughts, as many details as you can remember, and any insights you have.

<!-- chunk -->

### Be in nature. A walk in the woods, or on the beach, a hike up a mountain,

<!-- chunk -->

### and watching a sunset all have soothing effects on us and help us push

<!-- chunk -->

### that pause button.

<!-- chunk -->

### Listen to music. Certain types of music have soothing effects on our

<!-- chunk -->

### nervous system. Listen to Bach, Chopin, Mozart, Pachelbel, and Vivaldi.

<!-- chunk -->

### Or to traditional types of music such as Benedictine monks chanting or

<!-- chunk -->

### Sanskrit chants.

<!-- chunk -->

### Be artful. Painting, drawing, sculpting, or participating in any of the arts

<!-- chunk -->

### engages our brains and minds, creating a soothing and calming effect.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

# SPECIAL CONSIDERATIONS


<!-- chunk -->

### In addition to the steps outlined in the six-week program and the keys, there

<!-- chunk -->

### are a few special considerations I would like to address before I close.

# When You Need Therapy

<!-- chunk -->

### Sometimes it is not a toxin, allergen, infection, or nutrient-poor diet that

<!-- chunk -->

### makes us depressed or mentally ill. Sometimes it is just life itself—a divorce,

<!-- chunk -->

### childhood trauma, the death of a loved one, a crazy boss, or a major trauma.

<!-- chunk -->

### During those times in life, seeking help from a trained psychotherapist, a

<!-- chunk -->

### social worker, or even a personal coach can be lifesaving and may help guide

<!-- chunk -->

### you through troubled times.

<!-- chunk -->

### In traditional cultures, the family and social structure provided a container

<!-- chunk -->

### and meaning for all life’s events. Today, unfortunately, many of us are left alone

<!-- chunk -->

### to struggle through life’s transitions and questions. Getting support can help you

<!-- chunk -->

### heal and recover along with the UltraMind Solution.

# When You Need Medication

<!-- chunk -->

### As a former emergency room physician, I recognize that extreme times call

<!-- chunk -->

### for extreme measures. I use and support the intelligent, appropriate use of

<!-- chunk -->

### medication, including psychotropic medications when needed. They can often be

<!-- chunk -->

### helpful as a bridge for recovery from all the stresses and toxins that affect our

<!-- chunk -->

### brain and mind.

<!-- chunk -->

### It may take months or years to heal from damage that has occurred over a

<!-- chunk -->

### lifetime. In extreme cases, the damage may be so deep that full recovery is not

<!-- chunk -->

### possible using the UltraMind Solution (although most see remarkable results in a

<!-- chunk -->

### few weeks). In some cases, combining medication with the tools of the

<!-- chunk -->

### UltraMind Solution can give people their lives back.

<!-- chunk -->

### Working with an experienced psychopharmacologist who welcomes the

<!-- chunk -->

### integration of nutrition, supplements, exercise, and mind-body therapies is

<!-- chunk -->

### sometimes a necessary step to recovering a whole life.

<!-- chunk -->

### Many times medications can be reduced or eliminated after applying the

<!-- chunk -->

### principles found in the UltraMind Solution .

<!-- chunk -->

### I would caution you that psychotropic medications offer only partial

<!-- chunk -->

### solutions, often packaged with side effects. Tread intelligently, expect bumps on

<!-- chunk -->

### the road, and seek to find the causes of your suffering, which may be found in

<!-- chunk -->

### the stories of your life, on your plate, in your lifestyle, or in your toxic

<!-- chunk -->

### environment. You will rarely find the solution to your problems in a prescription

<!-- chunk -->

### bottle.

<!-- chunk -->

### If you need to, use medication without guilt just as you would any other

<!-- chunk -->

### tool to rebuild your life. And do not be afraid to put it down when you have

<!-- chunk -->

### rebuilt your health and your world.

# Special Herbs for the Brain

<!-- chunk -->

### A few other herbs and nutrients deserve special mention. I often find these

<!-- chunk -->

### beneficial in patients with mood or memory problems. I encourage you to work

<!-- chunk -->

### with your health-care practitioner when you use these herbs and nutrients. They

<!-- chunk -->

### can be used safely and effectively for many.

<!-- chunk -->

## Memory-Enhancing Herbs

<!-- chunk -->

## Huperzine A

<!-- chunk -->

### Huperzine A is derived from Chinese club moss and has shown significant

<!-- chunk -->

### benefits in dementia with few side effects. Clinical trials have shown that

<!-- chunk -->

### huperzine A is comparably effective to the drugs currently on the market, and

<!-- chunk -->

### may even be a bit safer in terms of side effects. It works by increasing

<!-- chunk -->

### acetylcholine in the brain, in a similar way to the current medications for

<!-- chunk -->

### Alzheimer’s.

<!-- chunk -->

### Currently, the National Institute on Aging is conducting a Phase II clinical

<!-- chunk -->

### trial to evaluate the safety and efficiency of huperzine A in the treatment of

<!-- chunk -->

### Alzheimer’s disease in a randomized controlled trial of its effect on cognitive


<!-- chunk -->

### The recommended dose is 100 mcg twice a day.

<!-- chunk -->

## Vinpocetine

<!-- chunk -->

### Vinpocetine is an extract of the periwinkle plant. More than fifty studies

<!-- chunk -->

### have found it effective in improving blood flow to the brain, improving energy

<!-- chunk -->

### production in the brain, and preventing blood clots.

<!-- chunk -->

### The recommended dose is 5 to 10 mg twice a day.

<!-- chunk -->

### If you are taking blood-thinning medicine, do not take this herb.

<!-- chunk -->

## Ginkgo biloba

<!-- chunk -->

### Ginkgo biloba is a powerful brain antioxidant and improves circulation. It

<!-- chunk -->

### has been used for thousands of years in traditional Chinese medicine for memory

<!-- chunk -->

### and mental health.

<!-- chunk -->

### Take Ginkgo Leaf Extract 80 to 160 mg twice a day (Ginkgo biloba)—

<!-- chunk -->

### standardized to 24 percent ginkgoflavonglycosides and 6 percent terpene

<!-- chunk -->

### lactones.

<!-- chunk -->

## Mood-Enhancing Herbs and Supplements

<!-- chunk -->

## St. John’s Wort

<!-- chunk -->

### St. John’s Wort contains many phytonutrients, called hypericins, that are

<!-- chunk -->

### helpful in the treatment of depression. It can be helpful in those with serotonin

<!-- chunk -->

### deficiency or with anxiety or sleep problems. Do not combine this with any other

<!-- chunk -->

### antidepressants or psychotropic medication (such as MAO inhibitors).

<!-- chunk -->

### The therapeutic dose is 300 to 450 mg twice a day.

<!-- chunk -->

## SAMe

<!-- chunk -->

### SAMe is an amino acid that is formed as part of your methylation cycle. It

<!-- chunk -->

### has been researched extensively and found effective for depression.

<!-- chunk -->

### Start with a dose of 400 mg four times a day, or 800 mg twice a day.

<!-- chunk -->

### A response usually occurs within three weeks and you can then reduce the

<!-- chunk -->

### dose to 400 mg twice a day.

<!-- chunk -->

### Use with your methylation supplement and magnesium.

<!-- chunk -->

### If you have bipolar disorder, use this amino acid only with your doctor’s

<!-- chunk -->

### supervision.
