## The Future of Medicine


<!-- chunk -->

### You will observe with concern how long a useful truth may be known

<!-- chunk -->

### and exist, before it is generally received and practiced upon.

<!-- chunk -->

### —

BENJAMIN FRANKLIN

<!-- chunk -->

### Many of my patients know intuitively that their various complaints must be

<!-- chunk -->

### related in some fashion. They don’t know exactly what’s wrong or how to find

<!-- chunk -->

### the answers, but they know that it is not in the type of medical care we have now.

<!-- chunk -->

### They understand that a health-care system focused on specialization and

<!-- chunk -->

### pharmacologic treatments of specific “diseases” often misses the underlying

<!-- chunk -->

### story of the origins and the reasons for their suffering.

<!-- chunk -->

### They intuitively know that a new approach to medicine, one in which we

<!-- chunk -->

### treat the underlying systems that cause disease when they are out of balance,

<!-- chunk -->

### would work better than the paradigm we are currently stuck in. They know this

<!-- chunk -->

### even if they have never heard the terms Functional Medicine or “systems

<!-- chunk -->

### biology.”

<!-- chunk -->

### Nonetheless, I, like almost every other doctor in the country, was trained to

<!-- chunk -->

### be a clinical pharmacologist, not a clinical physiologist, biochemist, geneticist,

<!-- chunk -->

### or practitioner of Functional Medicine. I was trained to dispense medication. I

<!-- chunk -->

### was not trained to process or understand biological information systems, or to

<!-- chunk -->

### make sense of patterns and relationships and connections in biological systems. I

<!-- chunk -->

### was not trained to see how everything communicates with everything else.

<!-- chunk -->

### However, by treating thousands of patients like Clayton (whom you learned

<!-- chunk -->

### about in Part I) and all the others you have learned about in this book for more

<!-- chunk -->

### than twenty years, and by studying the rich medical literature that explains, in

<!-- chunk -->

### detail, the way the underlying systems in our body create health or illness, I have

<!-- chunk -->

### been able to develop a whole new way of understanding medicine, one that is

<!-- chunk -->

### radically different than the method of diagnosis and treatment I was trained in.

<!-- chunk -->

### We are in the middle of an information revolution—not just in technology

<!-- chunk -->

### but also in biology. What I have studied and learned about for more than a

<!-- chunk -->

### decade now is the future of medicine. Functional Medicine and systems biology

<!-- chunk -->

### are the wave of the future, and it is what you just learned while you read The

<!-- chunk -->

### UltraMind Solution.

# Looking in the Wrong Place for Answers

<!-- chunk -->

### Could it be that we are looking in the wrong place for the answers to our

<!-- chunk -->

### epidemic of neurological and psychiatric disorders? Could it be that the

<!-- chunk -->

### medications we use for mood and brain disorders attempt to control the smoke

<!-- chunk -->

### while ignoring the fire?

<!-- chunk -->

### Could it be that these are, in fact, not primary brain disorders at all, but

<!-- chunk -->

### systemic disorders that affect the brain? And could it be that therapies primarily

<!-- chunk -->

### aimed at altering brain function through antidepressants, stimulants,

<!-- chunk -->

### antipsychotics, and seizure medications may miss the primary mechanisms or

<!-- chunk -->

### disturbances that show up as behavioral, mood, or neurological symptoms?

<!-- chunk -->

### New research shows clearly that the communication between the brain and

<!-- chunk -->

### the body is bidirectional. Even though Mind-Body Medicine has been studied

<!-- chunk -->

### and accepted as legitimate,


<!-- chunk -->

### it provides only a one-dimensional view of the

<!-- chunk -->

### interaction between the brain and the body.


<!-- chunk -->

### The conclusion from the science is irrefutable and must be heeded to

<!-- chunk -->

### effectively address the epidemic of “broken brains”—mood disorders, attention

<!-- chunk -->

### deficit disorder, autism, psychoses, Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, and other

<!-- chunk -->

### neurodegenerative disorders.

<!-- chunk -->

### Unless we focus on the metabolic, nutritional, and environmental influences

<!-- chunk -->

### that exert their effects on the brain through the body, we will not succeed in our

<!-- chunk -->

### efforts to promote mental and cognitive well-being.

<!-- chunk -->

### The next frontier in medicine is to define how “body” dysfunction or

<!-- chunk -->

### imbalances lead to abnormal brain chemistry and communication between brain

<!-- chunk -->

### cells, altered behavior, mood, and neurodegeneration.

<!-- chunk -->

### Today there is a new model of thinking in medical science. It is called

<!-- chunk -->

### Functional Medicine. It provides a new road map for navigating the mysteries of

<!-- chunk -->

### how the body works together as a whole system.

<!-- chunk -->

### Science is by nature reductionistic, breaking things into smaller and smaller

<!-- chunk -->

### parts and learning what each of them do separately. But what is missing in

<!-- chunk -->

### science is synthesis and integration. Putting the pieces of the puzzle back

<!-- chunk -->

### together. There are millions of bits of data and information, and yet for most

<!-- chunk -->

### practitioners of medicine they are strewn about the floor like a million puzzle

<!-- chunk -->

### pieces.

<!-- chunk -->

### Until we put the pieces of the puzzle together, we cannot see what picture it

<!-- chunk -->

### forms, or what story it tells us about the mystery of how the body works, and

<!-- chunk -->

### how the mind, brain, and body are all connected and intertwined.

<!-- chunk -->

### Functional Medicine is a method of putting those pieces together so we can

<!-- chunk -->

### see the picture of the whole clearly. It is not a new treatment or test or a new

<!-- chunk -->

### alternative method. It is just a way of putting together the pieces of the puzzle of

<!-- chunk -->

### chronic disease in a new way so we can truly see what is going on. It is a

<!-- chunk -->

### practical method of approaching each patient as an individual.

<!-- chunk -->

### The era of treating all depressed or anxious or ADHD or autistic or

<!-- chunk -->

### demented people the same way is over. There may be dozens of causes of

<!-- chunk -->

### depression or autism or dementia or ADHD. Finding the right cause and

<!-- chunk -->

### treatment for each individual will require a different way of practicing medicine.

<!-- chunk -->

### This is a radical shift from our conventional training where we use

<!-- chunk -->

### symptoms to make a diagnosis and then match a drug to that diagnosis. The

<!-- chunk -->

### science of genomics and molecular biology is forcing us to radically redefine

<!-- chunk -->

### disease. Could it be that many different “diseases” show up as the same

<!-- chunk -->

### symptoms? For example, can a nutritional deficiency, or a toxic level of mercury,

<!-- chunk -->

### or a food allergy all cause memory problems, attention deficit disorder, or

<!-- chunk -->

### depression?

<!-- chunk -->

### Today we know that they can.

<!-- chunk -->

### The symptoms may be exactly the same for people with the same label or

<!-- chunk -->

### “disease,” but the causes and treatment are completely different. The body (or

<!-- chunk -->

### brain) has only so many ways of saying ouch—sadness, happiness, anxiousness,

<!-- chunk -->

### forgetfulness, trouble with attention—but the reasons each person has that

<!-- chunk -->

### experience may be completely different.

<!-- chunk -->

### So how can we find a new model that gets to the root of the problem?

<!-- chunk -->

### This model already exists. This new medical paradigm has been laid out in

<!-- chunk -->

### detail in The Textbook of Functional Medicine (to which I contributed two

<!-- chunk -->

### chapters). It is a story of how all the pieces of the puzzle that create disease and

<!-- chunk -->

### promote health fit together. It is based on excellent science. There are about

<!-- chunk -->

### twenty thousand scientific references, and contributions from scientific giants.

<!-- chunk -->

### This model is the medicine of the future, but it is available to you today. It

<!-- chunk -->

### is what the seven keys to UltraWellness and the UltraMind Solution are based

<!-- chunk -->

### on, and it is what you have already begun to learn about in the pages of this

<!-- chunk -->

### book.

<!-- chunk -->

### But this road map is focused mostly on basic research. The practical

<!-- chunk -->

### application of this thinking is not being explored directly. But people do not need

<!-- chunk -->

### to wait twenty years to take advantage of this thinking. It is available now and it

<!-- chunk -->

### is the approach of Functional Medicine, or what I call UltraWellness

<!-- chunk -->

### (www.ultrawellness.com).

<!-- chunk -->

### It is only by teasing apart how each of these fundamental physiological

<!-- chunk -->

### processes alters brain function and studying how correcting them can restore

<!-- chunk -->

### normal function that a new model of psychiatry, neurology, and clinical

<!-- chunk -->

### neuroscience can emerge; one that provides more satisfactory answers than only

<!-- chunk -->

### partially effective pharmacologic treatments.

<!-- chunk -->

### The paradox is that in the detail of any one pattern or system of physiologic

<!-- chunk -->

### imbalance, the answer will not be found. It is only by putting together all the

<!-- chunk -->

### pieces of the puzzle, by assessing and treating all the imbalanced systems

<!-- chunk -->

### (nutritional, hormonal, inflammatory, immune, digestive, toxic, energy

<!-- chunk -->

### metabolism and oxidative stress, and mind-body) simultaneously that true

<!-- chunk -->

### advances can occur.

<!-- chunk -->

### Single drugs or methods are destined to fail. The nature of biology is that of

<!-- chunk -->

### a system, one whole, interdependent, interconnected system.

<!-- chunk -->

### In order to make real progress we must understand how our genes are

<!-- chunk -->

### affected by environment and lifestyle and how that leads to disturbances in

<!-- chunk -->

### cellular communication, physiology, and biochemistry, which are responsible for

<!-- chunk -->

### much of the accelerating rate of psychiatric and neurological disease in the

<!-- chunk -->

### twenty-first century.

<!-- chunk -->

### This new thinking will provide relief for millions if applied deliberately and

<!-- chunk -->

### carefully.

<!-- chunk -->

### * Brain allergies are reactions to food that can take many forms, including

<!-- chunk -->

### mood disorders, attention deficit disorder, autism, insomnia, and just plain brain

<!-- chunk -->

### fog.

†

<!-- chunk -->

### Autoimmunity is an abnormal immune response to the body’s own tissues.

<!-- chunk -->

### It usually occurs because of “molecular mimickry,” which is where the body

<!-- chunk -->

### confuses some of its own tissue with a foreign invader. In this case, antibodies

<!-- chunk -->

### against gluten also attack your own tissue.

*

<!-- chunk -->

### Those who have an SNP (single nucleotide polymorphism) or genetic

<!-- chunk -->

### variation of the enzyme THP2 have an 80 percent reduction in ability to make

<!-- chunk -->

### serotonin.

<!-- chunk -->

### The good news is that you can overcome this weakness by taking folate and

<!-- chunk -->

### the supplement 5-HTP (5-hydroxytryptophan), which is normally produced from

<!-- chunk -->

### 5-HTP dietary tryptophan, the molecule that is the next step in the process of

<!-- chunk -->

### making serotonin. If you take 5-HTP, you skip that weak step.

*

<!-- chunk -->

### Dr. Robert Heaney, one of the world’s leading vitamin D researchers, in a

<!-- chunk -->

### recent groundbreaking editorial in The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition

<!-- chunk -->

### about the delayed (yet very serious) consequences of taking less than the optimal

<!-- chunk -->

### amounts of nutrients for life, said that “because the current [vitamin]

<!-- chunk -->

### recommendations are based on the prevention of [deficiency] disease only, they

<!-- chunk -->

### can no longer be said to be biologically defensible. The pre-agricultural human

<!-- chunk -->

### diet... may well be a better starting point for policy. The burden of proof should

<!-- chunk -->

### fall on those who say that these more natural conditions are not needed and that

<!-- chunk -->

### lower intakes [of nutrients] are safe.”

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### detoxification.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### increased risks.

<!-- chunk -->

### Grass-fed means that the animals you eat spend their lives roaming and

<!-- chunk -->

### eating grass in a pasture, as they evolved doing. Grass-fed animals are not closed

<!-- chunk -->

### up in a stockyard, which means they have much less need for antibiotics. In

<!-- chunk -->

### addition, they move and eat a healthier, more natural diet, which means they are

<!-- chunk -->

### leaner. And they eat grass, which leads to higher amounts of omega-3 fats,

<!-- chunk -->

### vitamins, and minerals in the meat than grain-fed animals.
